awd_titl_txt: Conference: US Students Participation in the 23rd Course of ISCRA
awd_abstract_narration:
The International School of Cosmic Ray Astrophysics (ISCRA) is a biannual summer school designed to provide an overview of the field to graduate students and young postdoctoral scholars through both lectures and informal discussions with Particle Astrophysics experts.  This is the only regular Particle Astrophysics summer school and it has an excellent history of training future leaders.  This award offsets the total cost per participant and allows around 12 graduate students and young postdocs from the US to attend.  The ISCRA represents a major contribution to the education of these attendees.  Proceedings are also published for broad dissemination.

The 23rd ISCRA course will take place in Erice, Italy, from the 20th through the 28th of July 2024.  The theme of the course is “Multi-Messenger Astroparticle Physics”.  Discussions will include neutrino and gravitational wave astronomy, the highest energy particles, acceleration and interactions of high-energy radiation, balloon, satellite, and ground-based measurements, the propagation of high-energy radiation through the galaxy, and future space- or ground-based experiments.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The International Scholol of Cosmic Ray Astrophysics (ISCRA) - 23rd Course "Multi Messenger Astroparticle Physics" (MMAP) was held at the Ettore Majorana Centre in Erice, Italy from 20 to 28 July 2024. The school provided lectures by otustanding scientists who covered the latest results and also provided the background knowledge to make contribution to state of the art research.

This award supported twelve (12) Graduate students and postdoctoral scientists from the United States to participate in the 2024 ISCRA Workshop. The insitutions represented during this year's workshop were Georgia Institute of Technology (2), Michigan Technology University (1), Ohio State University (3), Pennsylvania State University (1), University of Chicago (2), University of Delaware (1), and Washington University in St. Louis (2).

By attending this workshop, the participants were given opportunities to attend formal discussion sessions as well as multiple opportunities for informal discussions with the lecturers. The lecturers were encouraged to share lunches and dinners with participants From such interactions, life-long friendships are made, new ideas emerged and collaborations form.

Over the last 46 years most of the scientists who now hold influential positions in cosmic-ray astrophysics have attended the ISCRA including several Nobel laureates, most attending before they won the prize.

Program:(x) identifies presenter. Presenter list is below the program

July 20, 2024: Welcome and Introduction (3)

July 21, 2024: Opening, Introduction -history of cosmic ray research (3), Gamma ray astronomy (1), Dark Matter Particle Exploration (5), Gamma rays (satellites) (4), Contribution of nearby active galaxy nuclei and starburst falaxies to the dipole of ultra high energy cosmic rays (7), and Likelihood reconstruction of neutrino and cosmic ray radio signals (11).

July 22, 2024: Ultra high energy cosmic rays (26), Gravitational waves (22), Multi messenger astroparticle physics (20), DAMPE (5), Gamma rays (satellites) (4), poster session (see photo)

July 23, 2024: Direct measurements of cosmic rays (25), Gamma ray astronomy (1), Multi messenger astroparticle physics (20), Ultra high energy cosmic rays (26), Gravitational waves (22), Towards an Autonomous Radio Trigger for the Detection of Air-Shower Radio Emission (10), The Moon Shadow using the Pierre Auger Observatory Data (23), The Payload for Ultrahigh Energy Observations (13), Highlights from the HAWC Observatory (27).

July 24, 2024: Neutrino astronomy (2), Gamma ray astronomy (1), Multi messenger astroparticle physics (20), Neutrino astronomy (2), Direct measurements of cosmic rays (25), The Radar Echo Telescope for cosmic rays (19), Cosmic Ray Interactions as a Bistatic Radar System (12), Deep Learning for the Reconstruction of MAGIC shower events (9), Time patterns of gamma-ray bursts light curves (14).

July 25, 2024: Neutrino astronomy (2), Cosmic ray theory (8), Cosmic rays at knee energies (3), Cosmic ray theory (8), Sources of ultra high energy cosmic rays (6), Extending the IceCube search for neutrino point sources in the Northern sky (16), 3D reconstruction of cosmic ray density in local galaxy (28), Probing quantum gravity through cosmic rays observations (18), GMRT observation of Unidentified PeVatron candidate LHAASO J2108+5157 (15).

July 26, 2024: excursion to Segesta and Selenunte

July 27, 2024: Gamma rays (satellites) (4), Radio detection of extensive air showers (3),  Cosmic ray theory (8), Gravitational waves (22), Ultra high energy cosmic rays (26), history of the ISCRA (24) and closing remarks (3).

Presenters included: 

(1) EGBERTS, Kathrin (Potsdam University); (2) HALZEN, Francis (UW-Madison); (3) HÖRANDEL, Jörg (Radboud University Nijmegen dep. Astrophysics);  (4) MORSELLI, Aldo (INFN Roma Tor Vergata)

(5) BERNARDINI, Paolo; (6) BISTER, Teresa; (7) DE OLIVEIRA, Caina; (8) EVOLI, Carmelo; (9) GREEN, Jarred; (10) KÖHLER, Jelena; (11) LANGGARD RAVN, Martin; (12) LINTON, Payton; (13) MACKEY, Scott; (14) MAGNUS, Else; (15) MAHANTA, Gunindra Krishna;  (16) MANAO, Elena; (17) MAURO, Jonathan; (18) MORAIS, Pedro Henrique; (19) NIVEDITA GOPINATH, Krishna; (20) OIKONOMOU, Foteini; (21) OSBORN, Nicole; (22) SCHMIDT, Patricia; (23) SIMKOVA, Katarina;  (24) SMITH, Arthur; (25) SPARVOLI, Roberta; (26) UNGER, Michael; (27) YU, Seonghyeon; (28) ZANDINEJAD, Hanieh
